segment.source: Windows Setup Supported Platforms and Cross-Platform Deployments
segment.target: Windows Setup Supported Platforms and Cross-Platform Deployments

segment.source: Windows Setup Supported Platforms and Cross-Platform Deployments
segment.target: Windows Setup Supported Platforms and Cross-Platform Deployments

segment.source: Windows Setup Supported Platforms and Cross-Platform Deployments
segment.target: Windows Setup Supported Platforms and Cross-Platform Deployments

segment.source: This topic describes the supported platforms and deployment scenarios for running for Windows Setup.
segment.target: This topic describes the supported platforms and deployment scenarios for running for Windows Setup.

segment.source: When you’re deploying different types of PCs, you can use Windows Setup as a way to choose between your images through the Windows Setup user interface to select a specific image.
segment.target: When you’re deploying different types of PCs, you can use Windows Setup as a way to choose between your images through the Windows Setup user interface to select a specific image.

segment.source: You can include images for a variety of hardware platforms (such as BIOS and UEFI, 32-bit and 64-bit PCs), and across different versions of Windows (such as Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2012 R2, and Windows 7).
segment.target: You can include images for a variety of hardware platforms (such as BIOS and UEFI, 32-bit and 64-bit PCs), and across different versions of Windows (such as Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2012 R2, and Windows 7).

segment.source: You can also run Windows Setup through a script.
segment.target: You can also run Windows Setup through a script.

segment.source: Boot the PC to Windows PE, and then use the sourcessetup.exe file to specify your image.
segment.target: Boot the PC to Windows PE, and then use the sourcessetup.exe file to specify your image.

segment.source: Firmware considerations: BIOS vs. UEFI
segment.target: Firmware considerations: BIOS vs. UEFI

segment.source: For UEFI-based PCs that support booting into either UEFI or legacy BIOS modes, make sure your PC is booted into the correct firmware mode before starting Windows Setup.
segment.target: For UEFI-based PCs that support booting into either UEFI or legacy BIOS modes, make sure your PC is booted into the correct firmware mode before starting Windows Setup.

segment.source: Otherwise, Windows Setup may set up the hard drive partitions incorrectly, or may abort the installation if the hard drives are preconfigured.
segment.target: Otherwise, Windows Setup may set up the hard drive partitions incorrectly, or may abort the installation if the hard drives are preconfigured.

segment.source: For more information, see WinPE: Boot in UEFI or legacy BIOS mode.
segment.target: For more information, see WinPE: Boot in UEFI or legacy BIOS mode.

segment.source: Firmware: BIOS 32-bit and 64-bit
segment.target: Firmware: BIOS 32-bit and 64-bit

segment.source: To set up a single environment or set of scripts that can deploy Windows to both 32-bit and 64-bit BIOS PCs, use a 32-bit version of Windows PE and a 32-bit version of Windows Setup.
segment.target: To set up a single environment or set of scripts that can deploy Windows to both 32-bit and 64-bit BIOS PCs, use a 32-bit version of Windows PE and a 32-bit version of Windows Setup.

segment.source: The 64-bit version of Windows Setup does not run on the 32-bit version of Windows PE.
segment.target: The 64-bit version of Windows Setup does not run on the 32-bit version of Windows PE.

segment.source: To install a 64-bit version of Windows from a 32-bit version of Windows PE:
segment.target: To install a 64-bit version of Windows from a 32-bit version of Windows PE:

segment.source: Boot the PC using the 32-bit version of Windows PE.
segment.target: Boot the PC using the 32-bit version of Windows PE.

segment.source: Use any of the following techniques to install a 64-bit version of Windows:
segment.target: Use any of the following techniques to install a 64-bit version of Windows:

segment.source: Run a 32-bit version of Windows Setup, and use the /InstallFrom command-line option to select a 64-bit Windows image:
segment.target: Run a 32-bit version of Windows Setup, and use the /InstallFrom command-line option to select a 64-bit Windows image:

segment.source: -or-
segment.target: -or-

segment.source: Run a 32-bit version of Windows Setup, and use the InstallFrom unattend setting to select a 64-bit Windows image.
segment.target: Run a 32-bit version of Windows Setup, and use the InstallFrom unattend setting to select a 64-bit Windows image.

segment.source: -or-
segment.target: -or-

segment.source: Use image-capturing tools to apply a 64-bit version of Windows to the PC.
segment.target: Use image-capturing tools to apply a 64-bit version of Windows to the PC.

segment.source: For more information, see Apply Images Using DISM.
segment.target: For more information, see Apply Images Using DISM.

segment.source: Warning
segment.target: Warning

segment.source: This procedure does not support deploying Windows 7.
segment.target: This procedure does not support deploying Windows 7.

segment.target: You can use the Windows 8.1 and Windows Server 2012 R2 versions of Windows Setup to install previous versions of Windows:

segment.source: You can also run Windows Setup from the Windows Preinstallation Environment (Windows PE).
segment.target: You can also run Windows Setup from the Windows Preinstallation Environment (Windows PE).

segment.source: Cross-Platform Deployment
segment.target: Cross-Platform Deployment

segment.source: Cross-platform deployment is the process of installing a specific architecture of Windows from an environment of a different architecture.
segment.target: Cross-platform deployment is the process of installing a specific architecture of Windows from an environment of a different architecture.

segment.source: For example, you can deploy a 64-bit edition of Windows 8.1 or Windows 8 from a 32-bit edition of Windows PE.
segment.target: For example, you can deploy a 64-bit edition of Windows 8.1 or Windows 8 from a 32-bit edition of Windows PE.

segment.source: The benefit of using a cross-platform deployment solution is that you don't have to maintain multiple versions of Windows PE for installing different architecture editions of Windows.
segment.target: The benefit of using a cross-platform deployment solution is that you don't have to maintain multiple versions of Windows PE for installing different architecture editions of Windows.

segment.source: You can build a single Windows PE image that you can use to install both 32-bit and 64-bit editions of Windows.
segment.target: You can build a single Windows PE image that you can use to install both 32-bit and 64-bit editions of Windows.

segment.source: When you install a 64-bit edition of Windows from a 32-bit version of Windows PE, you must use Windows PE 2.0 or a later version.
segment.target: When you install a 64-bit edition of Windows from a 32-bit version of Windows PE, you must use Windows PE 2.0 or a later version.

segment.source: For more information about Windows PE releases, see WinPE for Windows 10.
segment.target: For more information about Windows PE releases, see WinPE for Windows 10.

segment.target: The following table lists the different architecture types of Windows images (32-bit or 64-bit) that a specific version of Windows 8.1 Setup is able to install.

segment.source: Limitations of cross-platform deployment
segment.target: Limitations of cross-platform deployment

segment.source: These cross-platform deployment scenarios aren't supported:
segment.target: These cross-platform deployment scenarios aren't supported:

segment.source: Installing a 64-bit Windows image on a 32-bit computer.
segment.target: Installing a 64-bit Windows image on a 32-bit computer.

segment.source: Deploying a 32-bit Windows image from a 64-bit preinstallation environment.
segment.target: Deploying a 32-bit Windows image from a 64-bit preinstallation environment.

segment.source: Using a 32-bit version of Windows Setup to upgrade a 64-bit operating system.
segment.target: Using a 32-bit version of Windows Setup to upgrade a 64-bit operating system.

segment.source: Using a 32-bit version of Windows 8 Setup to deploy a 64-bit version of the Windows 7 operating system.
segment.target: Using a 32-bit version of Windows 8 Setup to deploy a 64-bit version of the Windows 7 operating system.

segment.source: For example, you must use a 64-bit version of Windows 8 Setup to deploy a 64-bit version of Windows 7.
segment.target: For example, you must use a 64-bit version of Windows 8 Setup to deploy a 64-bit version of Windows 7.

segment.source: In previous releases, the version of Windows Setup version had to match the operating system that you would deploy.
segment.target: In previous releases, the version of Windows Setup version had to match the operating system that you would deploy.

segment.source: For example, you had to use the Windows 7 Setup.exe to install Windows 7.
segment.target: For example, you had to use the Windows 7 Setup.exe to install Windows 7.

segment.source: Using Microsoft Internet SCSI (iSCSI) boot disk in a cross-platform deployment scenario.
segment.target: Using Microsoft Internet SCSI (iSCSI) boot disk in a cross-platform deployment scenario.

segment.source: For example, installing Windows (64-bit version) from cross-platform media, such as Windows PE (32-bit version), to an iSCSI boot disk is unsupported.
segment.target: For example, installing Windows (64-bit version) from cross-platform media, such as Windows PE (32-bit version), to an iSCSI boot disk is unsupported.

segment.source: You must use the same architecture for Windows PE as the target deployment architecture when you deploy Windows to an iSCSI boot disk.
segment.target: You must use the same architecture for Windows PE as the target deployment architecture when you deploy Windows to an iSCSI boot disk.

segment.source: On Unified Extensible Firmware Interface (UEFI), deploying a 64-bit edition of Windows from a 32-bit version of Windows PE.
segment.target: On Unified Extensible Firmware Interface (UEFI), deploying a 64-bit edition of Windows from a 32-bit version of Windows PE.

segment.source: On some UEFI computers, you can't install Windows in BIOS-compatibility mode and must switch to UEFI-compatibility mode.
segment.target: On some UEFI computers, you can't install Windows in BIOS-compatibility mode and must switch to UEFI-compatibility mode.

segment.source: For more information, see Boot to UEFI Mode or Legacy BIOS mode.
segment.target: For more information, see Boot to UEFI Mode or Legacy BIOS mode.

segment.source: On BIOS:
segment.target: On BIOS:

segment.source: Performing cross-platform deployments, except as part of a clean installation, or performing a Windows Deployment Services deployment.
segment.target: Performing cross-platform deployments, except as part of a clean installation, or performing a Windows Deployment Services deployment.

segment.source: Providing cross-platform installation media to users for recovery.
segment.target: Providing cross-platform installation media to users for recovery.

segment.source: To prevent users from installing the wrong edition of Windows for the architecture of their computer, don't provide cross-platform installation media to users for recovery or reinstallation.
segment.target: To prevent users from installing the wrong edition of Windows for the architecture of their computer, don't provide cross-platform installation media to users for recovery or reinstallation.

segment.source: Also, the Windows Recovery Environment (Windows RE) feature that's included on the media applies only to 32-bit Windows installations.
segment.target: Also, the Windows Recovery Environment (Windows RE) feature that's included on the media applies only to 32-bit Windows installations.

segment.source: Creating a .wim file for multiple architecture types
segment.target: Creating a .wim file for multiple architecture types

segment.source: If a .wim file contains both 32-bit and 64-bit Windows editions, you must select the Windows image that you want to install.
segment.target: If a .wim file contains both 32-bit and 64-bit Windows editions, you must select the Windows image that you want to install.

segment.source: Typically, Windows Setup uses the product key that you specify in the setting to determine which Windows image to install.
segment.target: Typically, Windows Setup uses the product key that you specify in the setting to determine which Windows image to install.

segment.source: But if the file contains 2 editions of the same Windows version, like Windows 8.1 Pro, you must use the setting in an answer file to specify the edition to install.
segment.target: But if the file contains 2 editions of the same Windows version, like Windows 8.1 Pro, you must use the setting in an answer file to specify the edition to install.

segment.source: To choose an image, specify metadata that corresponds to the image index, name, description, or architecture type.
segment.target: To choose an image, specify metadata that corresponds to the image index, name, description, or architecture type.

segment.source: For the metadata for architecture type, use 0 for 32-bit editions and 9 for 64-bit editions.
segment.target: For the metadata for architecture type, use 0 for 32-bit editions and 9 for 64-bit editions.

segment.source: For more info, see the Key setting.
segment.target: For more info, see the Key setting.

segment.source: The answer file must include processor-specific components.
segment.target: The answer file must include processor-specific components.

segment.source: The answer-file settings in the windowsPE configuration pass must match the architecture type of the preinstallation environment.
segment.target: The answer-file settings in the windowsPE configuration pass must match the architecture type of the preinstallation environment.

segment.source: The settings that apply to the Windows image must match the architecture type of the image.
segment.target: The settings that apply to the Windows image must match the architecture type of the image.

segment.source: For example, if you create an answer file that deploys 64-bit images from a 32-bit preinstallation environment, all components in the answer file for the windowsPE configuration pass must include the processor attribute type of x86.
segment.target: For example, if you create an answer file that deploys 64-bit images from a 32-bit preinstallation environment, all components in the answer file for the windowsPE configuration pass must include the processor attribute type of x86.

segment.source: Settings to be applied in the specialize, oobeSystem, or other configuration passes must include the processor attribute type of amd64.
segment.target: Settings to be applied in the specialize, oobeSystem, or other configuration passes must include the processor attribute type of amd64.

segment.source: Installing 64-bit drivers
segment.target: Installing 64-bit drivers

segment.source: All drivers that are included with Windows are signed.
segment.target: All drivers that are included with Windows are signed.

segment.source: In cross-architecture deployments, you can use an out-of-box device driver.
segment.target: In cross-architecture deployments, you can use an out-of-box device driver.

segment.source: But if you use an unsigned out-of-box device driver that's boot critical in a 64-bit installation, the installation may become unusable.
segment.target: But if you use an unsigned out-of-box device driver that's boot critical in a 64-bit installation, the installation may become unusable.

segment.source: You can install 64-bit drivers for a Windows image during Windows Setup in either of these ways:
segment.target: You can install 64-bit drivers for a Windows image during Windows Setup in either of these ways:

segment.source: In attended installations, you can press F6 or click the Load Driver button on the Disk Configuration page of Windows Setup.
segment.target: In attended installations, you can press F6 or click the Load Driver button on the Disk Configuration page of Windows Setup.

segment.source: In unattended installations, you can use the Microsoft-Windows-PnpCustomizationsWinPE or Microsoft-Windows-PnpCustomizationsNonWinPE component in an answer file to specify a driver path.
segment.target: In unattended installations, you can use the Microsoft-Windows-PnpCustomizationsWinPE or Microsoft-Windows-PnpCustomizationsNonWinPE component in an answer file to specify a driver path.

segment.source: For more information about how to automate your installation, see Automate Windows Setup.
segment.target: For more information about how to automate your installation, see Automate Windows Setup.

segment.source: Hardware considerations: Encrypted Hard Drives (e-Drives)
segment.target: Hardware considerations: Encrypted Hard Drives (e-Drives)

segment.source: We added support for Encrypted Hard Drive Devices (also known as E-Drives) in Windows 8, Windows Server 2012, and Windows PE 4.0.
segment.target: We added support for Encrypted Hard Drive Devices (also known as E-Drives) in Windows 8, Windows Server 2012, and Windows PE 4.0.

segment.source: To install a previous version of Windows (examples: Windows 7 or Windows Vista) to an Encrypted Hard Drive Device, use Windows PE 4.0 or later.
segment.target: To install a previous version of Windows (examples: Windows 7 or Windows Vista) to an Encrypted Hard Drive Device, use Windows PE 4.0 or later.

segment.source: For more information, see Encrypted Hard Drive Device Guide.
segment.target: For more information, see Encrypted Hard Drive Device Guide.
